The problem is about partitioning an array to maximize the sum of values. The value of a subarray is the length of the subarray if the sum is positive, negative of the length if the sum is negative, and 0 if the sum is zero.

We are provided with a code that uses a Fenwick tree (or segment tree) and coordinate compression for the prefix sums. The main idea is to use dynamic programming.

So if `pref[i]` is the same, then we compare `-i`. Since `-i` is negative and we are sorting in increasing order, the one with a larger `i` (which becomes more negative) will come later? 

But then we assign:

Note: `spos[i]` is a tuple `(pref_value, -index)`. So `spos[i][-1]` is `-index`. Then `-spos[i][-1]` is `index`. So `ordpos[index] = i` (the rank in the sorted list `spos`).

Similarly, for `sneg` we have `(pref[i], i)` and then `ordneg[sneg[i][-1]] = i` -> `sneg[i][-1]` is `i` (the index) and then `ordneg[i] = i` (the rank in `sneg`).

Then we have:

   For each i from 1 to n:
        dp[i] = max( 
            i + pfen.max(ordpos[i]), 
            nfen.max(n+1-ordneg[i]) - i, 
            dmx.get(pref[i], -INF)

Then we update the Fenwick trees and `dmx`.

The idea is that we consider three cases for the last segment ending at i:

1. The segment from j+1 to i has positive sum: then the value is (i - j). Then we have:
      dp[i] = dp[j] + (i - j)   => dp[i] = dp[j] - j + i
   So we want to maximize (dp[j] - j) for j such that the segment (j+1, i) has positive sum. The condition for positive sum is: pref[i] - pref[j] > 0  => pref[i] > pref[j].

2. The segment has negative sum: then the value is -(i - j) => dp[i] = dp[j] - (i - j) = dp[j] + j - i.
   Condition: pref[i] < pref[j].

3. The segment has zero sum: then the value is 0 => dp[i] = dp[j]. Condition: pref[i] == pref[j].

The Fenwick trees are used to handle the first two cases (with coordinate compression). The third case is handled by `dmx` (a dictionary that maps a prefix sum to the maximum dp value for that prefix).
